description:
Acidiphilium acidophilum is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Acidiphilium. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium.

Acidiphilium acidophilum is characterized by its ability to thrive in highly acidic environments, with an optimal growth pH range between 2.5 and 4.0. It is considered an acidophilic organism, meaning it prefers and can tolerate low pH conditions.

This species is typically found in acidic environments, such as acidic streams, mining sites, and soil habitats with high concentrations of heavy metals or sulfur compounds. Acidiphilium acidophilum plays a role in the biogeochemical cycling of elements in these acidic ecosystems.

Acidiphilium acidophilum is considered a chemoheterotrophic organism, meaning it obtains its energy and carbon sources from organic compounds. It is capable of oxidizing various organic acids and carbohydrates as energy sources.

The genome of Acidiphilium acidophilum has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic makeup and adaptations to thrive in acidic environments. This knowledge contributes to our understanding of the ecology and potential applications of this acidophilic bacterium.
